Name: BENZO(B)FLUORANTHENE
Description: Benzo[b]fluoranthene is an ortho- and peri-fused polycyclic arene that consists of a benzene ring fused with a acephenanthrylene ring. It has a role as a mutagen.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Sims RC, Overcash MR; Res Rev 88: 1-68 (1983) (2) Tremolada P et al; Environ Sci Technol 30: 3570-77 (1996) (3) Wild SR, Jones KC; J Environ Qual 21: 217-25 (1992) (4) Galuszka A; Chemosphere 67:1415-22 (2007) (5) Krommer V et al; Chemosphere 67:1956-66 (2007) (6) Wang Z et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 1336-41 (2009) (7) Ratola N et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 58: 631-47 (2010)
plant_concentrations.Value: Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in respective young and old leaves of beech at 62 and 374 ug/kg, oak at 62 and 292 ug/kg and tobacco at 32 and 126 ug/kg(1). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in pine needles of trees in the UK at 1.6-21.0 ng/g(2). The foliage of carrots, grown in soil amended with sewage sludge, contained <1 ug/kg of benzo(b)fluoranthene(3). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at 22-83 and 11-52 ng/g dry weight in moss species H. splendens and P. schreberi, respectively; samples were collected July 2005 from 10 locations in the southern part of the Holy Cross Mountains, Poland(4). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in moss samples from seven sites at 8.3-73 ng/g dry weight with a mean of 12.9 ng/g dry weight; samples were collected Sept 2005 from Wienerwald, Austria(5). In April 2005, pine needle samples were collected from 35 sites across Liaoning, China; benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at 4-30 ng/g dry weight(6). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in pine needle samples from 27 locations scattered all over the Portuguese continental territory at 2.7-43.4 and 1.0-103.0 ng/g dry weight in 19 Pinus pinea and 12 Pinus pinaster samples, respectively; samples were collected in April 2007(7).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Zhao Y et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 5853-9 (2006)
plant_concentrations.Value: In August 2003, bark from 15 species of trees (Xiamen, China) of different lipid content and surface area were sampled and the pseudo bark air partition coefficient (Kba) was calculated for benzo(b)fluoranthene(1).
plant_concentrations.Table: [{'Common name': 'Bailan', 'Genus species': 'Michelia alba', 'Kba': 6.97}, {'Common name': 'Lemon-scented gum', 'Genus species': 'Eucalyptus citriodora', 'Kba': 3.78}, {'Common name': 'Royal poinciana', 'Genus species': 'Delonix regia', 'Kba': 3.78}, {'Common name': 'Persimmon', 'Genus species': 'Diospyros khaki', 'Kba': 4.31}, {'Common name': 'Longan', 'Genus species': 'Dimocarpus longan', 'Kba': 7.48}, {'Common name': 'Weeping willow', 'Genus species': 'Salix babylonica', 'Kba': 16.36}, {'Common name': 'Lebbeck tree', 'Genus species': 'Albizia lebbeck', 'Kba': 6.65}, {'Common name': 'Purple bauhinia', 'Genus species': 'Bauhinia purpurea', 'Kba': 9.98}, {'Common name': 'Mango', 'Genus species': 'Mangeifera indica', 'Kba': 21.3}, {'Common name': 'Masson pine', 'Genus species': 'Pinus massoniana', 'Kba': 10.3}, {'Common name': 'Camphor tree', 'Genus species': 'Cinnamomum camphora', 'Kba': 12.1}, {'Common name': 'Astralian beefwood', 'Genus species': 'Casuarina cunninghamiana', 'Kba': 9.66}, {'Common name': 'Jambolan', 'Genus species': 'Syzygium cumini', 'Kba': 20.3}, {'Common name': 'Hoop pine', 'Genus species': 'Araucaria cunninghamia', 'Kba': 5.09}, {'Common name': 'Silky oak', 'Genus species': 'Grevillea robusta', 'Kba': 11.2}]

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Marsili L et al; Chemosphere 34: 759-770 (1997) (2) Cailleaud K et al; Chemosphere 70: 270-80 (2007) (3) Perugini M et al; J Agri Food Chem 57: 7440-4 (2009)
animal_concentrations.Value: Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in two colonies of sea lions (Otaria flavescens) off the coast of Argentina; concentrations were 7.62 and 9.18 ng/g for blood, and 0.13 and 0.12 ng/g for liver(1). Zooplankton (Eurytemora affinis) from the Seine Estuary (France) contained 15-559 ng/L of benzo(b,k)fluoranthene in samples collected Nov 2002 to Feb 2005(2). Drone honey bees collected May-Oct 2007 from eight sample locations in Italy contained benzo(b)fluoranthene at <0.04-0.10, <0.04-0.07 and <0.04-1.82 ng/g wet weight in unpolluted, moderately polluted and polluted sites, respectively(3).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Maccubbin AE et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 34: 876-82 (1985) (2) Dennis MJ et al; Food Chem Toxicol 21: 569-74 (1983) (3) El Deeb KZ et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 78: 373-9 (2007) (4) Malik A et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 80: 134-8 (2008) (5) Perugini M et al; Chemosphere 66: 1904-10 (2007)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in the stomach contents of bottom feeders at 3.24-17.0 ng/g in Lake Erie(1). Fish from England contained benzo(b)fluoranthene at 0.03-0.33 ppb with an average of 0.13 ppb(2). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at 99.05 and 71.71 ng/g wet weight in shrimp (Peneaus japonicus) and bottom feeding fish (Diplodus vulgaris), respectively; it was not detected in bottom feeding fish (Solea solea) and bivalve (Donax trunculus); samples were collected Feb 2004 from Abu Qir Bay, Egypt(3). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in 58.3% of the fish samples collected 2004 to 2005 from three sites on the Gomti River, India at detection limit to 6.61 ng/g wet weight(4). Ocean organisms were collected from Central Adriatic Sea, Italy in July and December 2004; benzo(b)fluoranthene was not detected (detection limit 0.25 ug/kg) in Norway lobster (Nephrops norvegicus), European flying squid (Todarodes sagittatus), Atlantic mackerel (Scomber scombrus) or blue whiting (Micromesistius potassou)(5). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in red mullet (Mullus barbatus) and European hake (Merluccius merluccius) at 0.28-0.98 and 0.25-0.90 ng/g wet weight, respectively in samples collected in July(5). In December samples, benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in Mediterranean mussels (Mitylus galloprovincialis) and red mullet at respective concentrations of 0.36-0.56 and <0.25-1.09 ng/g wet weight(5).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Mix MC, Schaffer RL; Marine Environ Res 9: 193-209 (1983) (2) Mix MC, Schaffer RL; Marine Pollut Bull 14: 94-7 (1983) (3) Howard JW, Fazio T; J Assoc Off Anal Chem 63: 1077-1104 (1980) (4) Bjorseth A et al; Sci Total Environ 13: 71-86 (1979) (5) Knutzen J, Sortland B; Water Res 16: 421-8 (1982) (6) Takatsuki K et al; J Assoc Off Anal Chem 68: 945-9 (1985) (7) Pittinger CA et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 4: 379-87 (1985) (8) Speer K et al; J High Res Chromatogr 13: 104-111 (1990) (9) Pereira WE et al; Mar Pollut Bull 24: 103-109 (1992) (10) Nakata H et al; Ecotoxicol Environ Saf 99: 61-8 (2014) (11) Namiesnik J et al; Chemosphere 73: 938-44 (2008) (12) Fabbri D et al; Chemosphere 64: 1083-92 (2006) (13) Kucuksezgin F et al; Chemosphere 93: 1511-8 (2013)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Oysters from Yaquina Bay, OR contained benzo(b)fluoranthene at 0.25-5.1 ppb (remote site) and 10.4-24.4 ppb (site proximal to industry)(1). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in softshell clams in Oregon at 0.9-2.3 (remote site), 1.5 ppb average; 10.5-14.8 ppb (site proximal to industry), 12.1 ppb average(2). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in oysters in Maryland at 0.3, 1.2 and 2.2 ppb collected from low pollution, area approved for oyster harvesting and closed areas, respectively(3). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in mussels from Norway at 1653-56,509 ppb(4), 16-176 ug/kg, 3-30 ug/kg and 48-90 ug/kg(5). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in mussels from Miyagi Prefecture, Japan at 0.83-1.94, 2.17, 1.37 and 0.82-1.87 ppb in mussels, oysters, corb-shells and shortneck clams, respectively(6).  Benzo(b,k)fluoranthene isomers were detected at concentrations up to 1.0 ug/g dry weight in oysters taken from a variety of locations around the US(7). Mean concentrations of combined benzo(b,j,k)fluoranthene isomers were detected in fresh oysters at 4.5-12.2 ug/kg wet weight(8). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in clams at 60-108 ng/g(9). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in bivalves collected July to Oct 2008 from 18 locations in Yatsushiro Sea, Japan at 0.31-39 ng/g wet weight(10). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at <1 ug/kg dry weight in mussels (Mytilus galloprovincialis) from polluted and non-polluted areas of Mokpo Bay, Korea, collected April 10, 2004(11). Mussels (Mytilus galloprovincialis), were translocated from 20 miles off the coast of Marina de Ravenna in the Adriatic Sea to locations in 3 coastal lagoons of Ravenna, Italy; the concentration of benzo(b,k)fluoranthene was <5 ng/g dry weight, measured before and after 30 days of relocation(12). Mussels (Mytilus sp.) from nine locations along the Aegean coast, collected in 2011 contained benzo(b)fluoranthene at 5.27-6.64 ng/g dry weight(13).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Coakley JP et al; Estuaries 16: 653-69 (1994) (2) Great Lakes Water Quality Board 1987 Report on Great Lakes Water quality Appendix B- Great Lakes surveillance, Vol 3 Report To the International Joint Commission (1989) (3) Johnson AC et al; Marine Environ Res 15: 1-16 (1985) (4) Prahl FG et al; Environ Sci Technol 18: 687-93 (1984) (5) Merrill EG, Wade TL; Environ Sci Technol 19: 597-603 (1985) (6) Echols KR et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 55: 161-72 (2008) (7) Debruyn JM et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 3467-73 (2009) (8) Hawthorne SB et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 25: 2901-2911 (2006) (9) Huang L et al; Sci Total Environ 487: 173-86 (2014) (10) Khalil MF, Ghosh U; Environ Sci Technol 40: 5681-7 (2006)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples from the St Lawrence River (0.03-0.10 ug/g)(1) and the Detroit River (0.12-30.70 mg/kg)(2). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in Penobscot Bay, ME surficial sediments at 17-1000 ppb dry weight(3) and coastal Washington state at 32-35 ng/g dry sediment(4). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected, not quantified, in sediments from the Elizabeth River in Virginia(5). In sediment samples collected Oct 28 to Nov 6, 2002 from 19 locations on the lower Missouri River, benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at 7.8-165 ng/g dry weight(6). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples from seven locations on Lake Erie at not detected to 1.96 mg/kg; samples were collected in Aug 2006(7). Benzo(b,k)fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples from 114 sites from 8 historically contaminated locations in New York and North Carolina at 0.02-418 ug/g; samples were collected 2003 to 2005(8). Pore water concentrations of benzo(b,k)fluoranthene from 51 of these samples were not detected to 2.1 ng/g(8). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at 13.2-71.9 ng/g dry weight in 24 samples collected Aug 16-19, 2011 from the southern part of Lake Michigan(9). Seven sediment samples collected in the vicinity of a former manufactured gas plant on the Hudson River, NY contained 5.1-56.3 mg/kg of benzo(b)fluoranthene; samples were collected in 2003(10).

New Yorki, NY: Von Nostrand Reinhold p. 275 (1996) (6) El Deeb KZ et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 78: 373-9 (2007) (7) Fabbri D et al; Chemosphere 64:1083-92 (2006) (8) Guo W et al; Chemosphere 68: 93-104 (2007) (9) Hiller E wt al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 83: 444-8 (2009) (10) Hori T et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 83: 455-61 (2009) (11) Li Q et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 58: 711-21 (2010) (12) Maranho LA et al; Ecotoxicology 24: 368-80 (2015)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at 0.01 ug/g in one of eight sediments collected Aug 25-Sept 12 1985 and June 21-July 1, 1986 from the Mackenzie River, Canada(1). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was also reported in sediment samples from Macaulay Point, Canada (50-2910 ug/kg)(2). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in the Tamar Estuary, Great Britain at a concn of 475 ng/g (dry weight)(3) and in Saudafjord, Norway at 21.0-8212.1 ppb dry weight (0-2 cm), 40.0-4678.3 ppb dry weight (2-4 cm), 5.7-2853.2 ppb dry weight (4-6 cm), 4.0-2,907.9 ppb dry weight (6-8 cm)(4). Benzo(b)fluoranthene isomers were detected at 30-110 and 25-35 ppb in dried forest soil samples taken from south of Darmstadt and near Lake Constance, West Germany, respectively(5). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in 17 of 20 sediment samples collected June 2004 form Abu Oir Bay, Egypt at 4.23-22.80 ng/g dry weight(6). Benzo(b,k)fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples from three coastal lagoons of the Adriatic Sea in Ravenna, Italy at <20-1400 ng/g dry weight(7). Sediment samples taken from the Hun, Taizi and Daliao rivers in China contained 0.63-9.13, 2.70-18.91 and 1.74-8.98 ng/g dry weight of benzo(b)fluoranthene, respectively; samples were collected Aug 2005(8). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples collected June 2005 from the Ruzin, Velke Kozmalovce and Zemplinska Sirava reservoirs in Slovakia at 227-544, 336-678 and 8-70 ng/g dry weight(9). Benzo(b,j,k)fluoranthene was detected at 3.0-674ng/g dry weight in sediment samples collected Nov 2005 to Apr 2006 from 14 sites on the Shinano River, Japan(10). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at 20.1-139.7 ng/g in sediment samples collected Sept 21, 2007 from Xiamen Bay, China(11). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at 4.41-81.52 and <2.00-120.20 ng/g in sediment samples collected in March and Sept 2011, respectively, from six sites in the Bay of Cadiz, Spain(12).

sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in soil samples collected July 21-23, 1992 from Boston and Springfield, MA, and Providence, RI at 0.049-12.00 mg/kg with an average of 1.4 mg/kg(1). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in soil samples collected from 49 locations in Wales at 7-4600 ug/kg dry weight(2). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in 188 top soil samples from the Tianjin, China at an approximate geometric mean of 0.06 ug/g; areas of sampling included farmland using wastewater irrigation, common farmland, mountainous are, wild land, oil field and city greenbelt(3). Surface soils from nine representative vegetable fields located in Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Zengcheng and Huadu, China contained benzo(b)fluoranthene at not detected to 1900 ug/kg; samples were collected the summer of 2002(4). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at 0.02-1.6 mg/kg in soil samples collected from eight locations around the city of Esbjerg, Denmark(5). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected in soil at 5 ug/g; sample was collected from a plastics company involved in a major fire in 1997 in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada(6). Benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at 2.77-1500 ng/g dry weight (mean and median; 122 and 47.1 ng/g dry weight) in 201 soil samples from 32 different land types collected from across Great Britain(7). In 216 soil samples collected from agricultural fields in 2005 from Poland, benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at 5-548 ug/kg(8). The mean concentration of benzo(b)fluoranthene was reported as 1.53, 1.32, 1.27 and 0.92 ug/g in 319 soil samples collected from industrial, roadside, residential and agricultural land use areas of Agra, India, respectively(9). Benzo(b)fluoranthene concentrations in dry months of 2008 were 0.39 and 0.16 ng/kg, and 0.73 ng/kg in wet months of 2009; samples were collected from crop lands in Mexico City, Mexico(10). In April 2005, soil samples were collected from 35 sites across Liaoning, China; benzo(b)fluoranthene was detected at 14-414 ng/g dry weight(11).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Garcia-Galcon MS et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 759-63 (2006)
